case_name: Hindustan Lever Ltd. v. Mazdoor Sabha

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 675 to 681 of 1967 filed by Hindustan Lever Ltd. by special leave from Award dated March 23, 1967 of Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 675 to 681 of 1967. Appeals by special leave from the Award dated March 23 1967 of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Misc. Cases Nos. 161, 160, 162-64 and 167 of 1966.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1759 of 1971 filed by Mazdoor Sabha by special leave from Award dated August 11, 1969 of Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: AND Civil Appeal No. 1759 of 1971 Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 11, 1969 of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, Calcutta in Case No. VIII-373 of 1966 published in the Calcutta Gazette dated 27-9-1969.

facts.text: Hindustan Lever Ltd. Calcutta Branch concerned only with marketing.

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta Branch was companycerned only with marketing. From the year 1956 at least, if number earlier, the companypanys marketing Organisation was in three divisions, the Soaps Division, the Foods Division and the Toilet Preparations Division.

facts.text: From 1956, marketing organization in three divisions: Soaps, Foods, Toilet Preparations.

anchor.surface_text: From the year 1956 at least, if number earlier, the companypanys marketing Organisation was in three divisions, the Soaps Division, the Foods Division and the Toilet Preparations Division.

facts.text: On 6-9-66, company reorganized marketing into two divisions: Main Lines and Speciality Lines.

anchor.surface_text: From 6-9-66 the Company reorganised this marketing Organisation into two divisions- the Main Lines Division and the Speciality Lines Division.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred question to Third Industrial Tribunal on 30-9-66.

anchor.surface_text: On 30-9-66 the Government of West Bengal referred to the Third Industrial Tribunal the following question for adjudication Is the human rationalisation as a measure of economic reorganisation of the Company reflected through job-integration that have either been effected or proposed to be effected justified,? To what relief, if any, are the workmen entitled?

facts.text: Pending adjudication, seven workers filed s.33A applications alleging adverse change in service conditions and non-payment of October 1966 salary.

anchor.surface_text: Pending adjudication of this issue seven workers filed applications under section 33A of the Industrial Disputes Act before the same. Tribunal alleging that during the pendency of the adjudication their service companyditions had been changed adversely and their salary for the month of October 1966 had number been paid.

facts.text: Tribunal held in favor of workers in s.33A cases on 23-3-1967.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held in favour of the workers and passed its award on 23-3-1967. By special leave granted by this Court the employer has filed the above 7 appeals.

facts.text: Main reference disposed on 11-8-69 in favor of employer.

anchor.surface_text: The main reference was finally disposed of on 11-8-69 by the same Tribunal holding in favour of the employer and the workers have, therefore, filed Civil Appeal No. 1759 of 1971 by special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Reorganisation did not result in any retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the re- organisation has number resulted in any retrenchment.

facts.text: Employer assured no retrenchment during negotiations.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, during the companyrse of rather prolonged negotiations between the parties the employer made it abundantly clear again and again that numberbody would be retrenched.

facts.text: Workers refused to work under new scheme, employer refused to pay wages for October 1966.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that the workers, presented themselves for work every day and offered to work according to the old scheme but that they were number given any work according to the old scheme They were told that as long as they refused to work under the new scheme they would be paid numberwages.

facts.text: Salesmen handled products of more than one division since 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also found that the Salesmen of the companypany did in fact handle products of more than one division at, a time in the companyrse of joint selling operation since 1960.

facts.text: Integrated selling in Assam since 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It was admitted that they also did it in the companyrse of integrated selling in Assam since 1964 but that is said to be because that was done on an experimental basis.

facts.text: No increase in workload as per main tribunal finding.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has gone elaborately into the question of workload and companye to the companyclusion that there is numberincrease in the workload.

facts.text: Journey cycles increased from 4 weeks to 6.5 weeks, but avoided in practice.

anchor.surface_text: He further urged that the Journey Cycles, i.e. the period during which salesmen were expected to be on tour companytacting the various dealers were increased from 4 weeks to 6 1/2 weeks and that this also proved a greater burden on the salesmen.

facts.text: Three godowns reduced to two.

anchor.surface_text: He also urged that three godowns which previously existed were reduced to. two godowns and that proved a greater burden on the Godown Keeper.

facts.text: Scheme of reorganisation: regrouping products, redeploying staff geographically, reorganizing trade outlets, redeploying sales force.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of reorganisation in this case was Firstly, as a result of the regrouping of the products from the three divisions into two lines, the sales management staff of the companypany was redeployed on a geographical basis instead of product group basis. Secondly, the employer reorganised its trade outlets so that ReDistribution Stockists would handle all the products of the companypany rather than the products of any particular division. Thirdly, the entire sales force was redeployed over two products groups, i.e. Main Lines and Speciality Lines.

facts.text: s.33A Tribunal found conditions changed to prejudice, workload increased, retrenchment likely.

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence it held that the Union had the apprehension that the proposed reorganisation would result in some members of the staff becoming surplus, and that this apprehension was number without justification, and that the apprehension became true when the reorganisation was actually introduced. It also held that the workload of the various applicants increased as a result of the reorganisation.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds both awards.

anchor.surface_text: On an exhaustive companysideration of the material in both the awards we have companye to the companyclusion that both the awards should be upheld.

facts.text: Reorganisation introduced on 5th or 6th September 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Technically numberdoubt this companytention is companyrect because the scheme was introduced on the 5th or 6th of September and the reference was made on 30th of September.

facts.text: Voluntary retirements occurred, some posts not filled.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, urged on behalf of the workers that there have been a number of voluntarily induced retirements and that many posts were number filled after the holders of these posts had retired or left.

facts.text: Different presiding officers in two cases.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned that the Presiding Officer of the Industrial Tribunal was different in the two cases but the different companyclusions arrived at by the two Presiding Officers were number due to the accident of difference in personnel.

facts.text: Evidence in main reference vast, led to favor employer; in 33A cases meagre, favor workers.

anchor.surface_text: There was a vast mass of evidence let in by the employer in the main reference on a companysideration of which the Tribunal held in favour of the employer. On the other hand the evidence in the applications, filed under section 33A of the Industrial Disputes Act, let in by the employer was meagre

holdings.text: Section 9A is not attracted to the reorganisation scheme in the main reference.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that section 9A is not attracted. It is, therefore, unnecessary to consider the question whether the argument advanced by Shri Gupte on behalf of the employer that in view of the very prolonged and detailed discussions that went on between the parties there was a substantial compliance with provisions of section 9A and the mere fact that a formal notice was not given under section 9A would not make the reorganisation scheme not valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No change in terms and conditions of service to workers' detriment based on Tribunal's supported findings; no reassessment under Art 136.

holdings.text: Non-payment of wages in the circumstances of this case amounts to an alteration in the conditions of service.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment of wages is essential condition; continued refusal during pendency due to justified worker refusal is permanent alteration, distinguished from single default under s.33C.

holdings.text: The fact that the scheme was introduced before the reference under section 10 was made does not bar an application under section 33A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applications concern October wages post-reference; s.33A treated as s.10 reference; continued non-payment during pendency.

holdings.text: The retrenchment contemplated under item 10 is retrenchment as defined in s.2(oo), which does not include voluntary retirement; reorganisation not likely to lead to retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the retrenchment contemplated under item 10 is retrenchment as defined in clause (oo) of section 2 where it is defined as the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, but does not include voluntary retirement of the workman.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition excludes voluntary retirement; no retrenchment occurred despite voluntary retirements/non-filling; assurances given.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was justified in concluding that the alteration in conditions of service could not have been made without notice under section 9A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33A Tribunal found prejudice and likely retrenchment on meagre evidence; upheld as supported.

holdings.text: Voluntary retirement and non-filling of vacancies do not constitute retrenchment under item 10.

anchor.surface_text: The workers cannot, therefore. make a grievance of the voluntary retirement and not-filling of vacancies and try to bring it under item 10.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(oo) excludes voluntary retirement; retrenchment requires employer termination.

holdings.text: Both awards of the Tribunal should be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: On an exhaustive consideration of the material in both the awards we have come to the conclusion that both the awards should be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different evidence volumes led to different conclusions; both supported, no perversity under Art 136.

holdings.text: Employer has right to organise work as pleases, subject to s.9A.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no dispute that the employer has got the right to organise his work in the manner he pleases as was held in Parry's case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Parry's case; subject to statutory limits like s.9A.

holdings.text: Under Art 136, no interference with Tribunal fact findings unless unsupported by evidence or perverse.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in considering a matter under Article 136 does not ordinarily re-assess the evidence on the basis of which the Tribunal came to its conclusions. It will interfere with the findings of facts by the Tribunal only if it is unsupported by any evidence or is wholly perverse.
